title: Will Jurassic World (2015) pass Titanic (1997) to become the #2 all-time highest-grossing movie domestically by the end of the year?
preds: Twelve hours to go and not even close.
Not likely given Titanic is ahead by almost 700 million.
It is no longer at cinemas
doesn't look like it is even close at this point.
Star wars will make this target.
There is no chance statically. It will likely pull in something like $652,380 by the end of the year. Which is about 6 million less than what Titanic made.
According to this website, Jurassic World is only 6 million behind Titanic in domestic box office:
Close but no close enough. I like the research done by Fetty_1
People aren't still seeing Jurassic World; they're seeing Star Wars
Dinosaurs are history, robots are the future and love is forever.  Unless it's a lovE story (and dinosaurs I think, don't do love very well) it's not gonna top Titanic

As at 26 December, Titanic made $658 million and Jurassic World made $652 million, which means Jurassic World has to bridge a gap of approximately $6.4 million in the next five days. That is highly unlikely to happen. The movie's weekly gross has been consistently decreasing, and the last available figure was $98,000 for the week of Nov 13-19. Even if the weekly gross figure suddenly increases compared to the previous week(s) - which has never happened since the film was released in May 2015 - it is highly unlikely to reach over a million a week, especially since most people are going to more recent movies right now e.g. Star Wars, Spectre.

Star Wars: The Force Awakens is going to steal box office share of wallet thereby preventing Jurassic World from closing the $500MM gap between its YTD global sales and Titanic's. In order to do so, we would need $70MM in global box office sales per day before year end....or 30% of it's YTD take...not gonna happen folks.
Its frankly has not captured the publics imagination at all, also recent release

There is no way the movie can make it even if the remaining theaters showing it, sell out 24/7 for the remaining of the year.  The actual rate may not be 0 but it is possibly 100x closer to 0 than to 1.
They are ~6.5M USD from the target with one week to go and doesn't seem to be playing in any theatres. I think the better question is whether Star Wars: The Force Awakens will make it to a top spot.
It is still a way off and is near the end of its run. Also, Jurassic World doesn't have the same hype Titanic did.
It would need to generate ~$7MM, but is only averaging $100k per week at this point.
Star Wars will finish the year off.
Star Wars will stop it from reaching #2.  It's unlikely to pass Titanic anyhow
Changing from 1% to 0% because there is too little time left for any significant box office change.
Unlikely to exceed due to flippant nature of film
It peaked early and is now not even showing anywhere that it will be seen,

While Jurassic World had a massive first weekend launch, it is no classic and ticket sales quickly subsided while Titanic kept going strong for many weeks after release. Considering that it is no longer showing in any but a handful of theatres, while Titanic was popular enough to be re-released in 2012 and is still showing in some of the more classically inclined venues, it seems that Jurassic World is extremely unlikely to ever catch up - much less by year end. One should also consider that taking into account inflationary movements, Titanic took in around 40% more domestic sales than Jurassic World and was also a much bigger success internationally.
It might pass Titanic. It will not pass Star Wars: TFA
There is still 500 million dollars between the two films and growth in Jurassic World's box office takings is slow
Jurassic World isn't far behind but it is still a steep target to beat given it has been out for a while.
Just based on forlorn hope in humanity's capacity for some aesthetic discernment
I really believe that TITANIC will retain its number two position in the ratings.

I think the US has the same decline in cinema goes as the UK.  Not sure what cost of cinema tickets is though? Not seemed to have the same publicity but might be different in US? Hedged my bets on this one but have put it less likely.
Long awaited film. More people in a position to attend cinema due to increased financial stability.

To all those who have been kind enough to comment on my forecasts:  Thanks very much.  I obviously know nothing about the entertainment industry, but the data you have forwarded has helped.  In light of overwhelming evidence contrary to my initial opinion, I must change my forecast once again in favor of the facts.   DARN FACTS!
       Every day I learn something new is a day worth living.  Thanks very much again.

It's initial release volume was significant and ticket prices materially higher in 2015 than in 1997 however it's not showing in theatres will be streamed, downloaded or bought rather than viewed at the box office where it remains significantly short of Titanic gross income.
It will be beaten by the new Star Wars film
Because there are more people in the world and movie  goers than in 1997
Jurassic world is not a very good film
Affirming prior prediction, following the super-duperforecasters.

Reduced forecast from 45% to 25% because within the past week the rate of change in the earnings ratio between the two has remained unchanged.  I had anticipated the -0.972% difference would have moved closer to zero.
J2 did not, in my opinion,  meet all the hype put out prior to being released.
The numbers of theaters running it is consistently going down and even at the current run rate it isn't even close to make it. It maybe not be 0 exactly but it is closer to 0 than to 1.
Jurrasic World have only 19 days to ketch up. In comparison Titanic have about have a billion advantage over Jurrasic.

Titanic 658M gross
Jurassic World : 652M as of Dec 11th so needs only 1% growth in 20 days during Xmas or 6M revenues:
6M/$8= 750,000 tickets or 37,500 per day
Still in about 100 theater as end of November or 375 tickets per day per theater: this sounds highly unlikely.
Decelerated income over recent months and insufficient time to draw required revenue.

About 5.5 weeks of data to be released, seems to be doing about $100,000 / week now and still about $6,000,000 short of Titanic, so it doesn't look like this is going to happen. Thanksgiving figures not out yet, which present potential surprise, but still rate low chance. And it's not like there isn't going to be something else big in the cinema over Xmas!

I am reducing my forecast from 99% to 45%.  I'll continue to monitor the numbers as the holiday approaches, then analyse and adjust as appropriate.
Never, still a huge gap from $1,668.9 (3rd) to $2,186.8 (2nd)
Consensus indicates Jurassic World has surpassed Titanic.  Now we must see what the professional bean counters say.
With no indication of getting a wide re-release, there is not enough time nor screen count to catch-up to Titanic.
Weekly gross numbers would have to quadruple in the time remaining.  All the spooks following GJP should take a day off and go see "Bridge of Spies."
Plenty of time left for only a small needed gain
There will be too much competition over the rest of the year.  Most of those who wanted to see the movie have already done so.
Needs to make up more than 6M and it needed to make more than 6M before Thanksgiving which some thought would give it a bump. Unless Christmas gives an absurd bump it isn't going to happen.
If the hype means anything,  it will do well even if it isn't a particularly good movie.
Oh, then no way, it's still behind by $6 million.

I'm giving a 1% chance because Jurassic World opened in South Korea during the MERS outbreak http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/south-korea-mers-surprising-impact-804455. It's been 6 months so there is a chance people are no longer cautious about getting sick at the movie, so there is a chance... a very small chance.
Even if weekly gross were held constant at 100X current levels, it wouldn't be enough.

It's currently playing in only 109 theatres and made $98,090 this past weekend: http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekly/chart/?yr=2015&wk=46&p=.htm
It needs $6million to pass Titanic. Only a very wide re-release before year end would give a chance to pass Titanic.
Seems essentially impossible.  In fewer and fewer theaters, making dozens (dozens!) of dollars per theater.  Moving from 3 to 0.

At present time the weekly gross is $160K for Jurassic World, and with 6 weeks left in the year it is highly unlikely the $6.5MM gap will be closed, especially with the upcoming holiday release schedule of newer movies.

There's only 7 million in gross revenues between the two movies.  Moveover, Jurassic is still in the theaters.  One big, crazy bump of interest at Thanksgiving or Xmas, and Jurassic World could overtake Titanic.  It's unlikely, but not impossible.
so close, yet so far away.
Latest trend is negative but Thanksgiving weekend and December effect can have a material impact on total sales, therefore the low probability but possible upgrade

So, for the november 13-15 week, this movie has fallen to the 39th place. it has picked back up during the course of the 23 weeks it has been around, but given the fact that there is no further surge, and the weekend gross has dipped for the first time to less than 100,000$, it clearly shows a decline in the upcoming weeks.

to surpass titanic, current weekly take must be maintained through to the end of the year.  with holidays coming up, and new releases coming out accordingly, potential viewers will be taken away from jurassic world.  thus, maintaining current levels weekly through to the end of the year is unlikely.
Too far behind. Too few screens still showing in US markets.
As of November 13th it is $2 million behind in overall gross. But as of October it was pulling in less than $250k per weekend so with 6 weeks left in the year it is unlikely to pass Titanic.

http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekly&id=jurassicpark4.htm
Slowing down too much to close $6M in 6 weeks.

Once a film has hit the DVD shelves it is hard to find any release that has had a further upsurge in box office.  However being within 1% of the relevant number, it is not beyond the realms of possibility that something might affect the outcome over a 6 week period, even a counting error.
Updating for continued downward trend in box office revenues.
JW needs $6 million more to close the gap.  It only had $166K in the last week of October.  It needs to average $750K per week over the final 8 weeks and the trend has shown diminishing returns.

The chances of this happening are slim to none.  While it rocked at the box office.....it did not have the audience that Titanic had which captured every age group of people.  Jurassic World does not.  Key factor at the box office. Plus, Titanic was a REAL story with fictional characters thrown in.  Brilliant marketing for mixing history with fiction.  Look at the volumes Dan Brown has sold in his books by doing the same thing.  Jurassic World was a fabulous fictional roller coaster of a ride movie.  However, it doesn't have the substance that Titanic had to reach that level of activity.  Even with mass marketing.  Even with ticket sales more expensive than when Titanic came out.  Not going to happen.

Unless the number of theaters currently showing the movie goes up by a factor of 4.6 (at least) I don't think there's a real chance for Jurassic World to pass Titanic's domestic lifetime gross of $658,672,302 by 12/31/2015.

All splash, no dash. Too many new titles coming out that will pull off viewers

Needs to be doing about $110,000 a day, last week was around $26,000 and declining. If it's not showing in theaters (as seems to be the case) then it can't get there. The gap is small in absolute terms though, about 1% between the two movies, so the main risk is that Box Office Mojo changes it methodology or restates numbers for 2015 in some way (e.g. decides it missed some chain of theaters for part of 2015 or something).

Requires $7m of business in 9 weeks. Last week did $250,000, and has fallen week on week reliably. There is no real precedent for a summer blockbuster film to have a bump in weekly earnings at the end of the year, looking at Dark Kinight Rises, Dark Knight, Avengers and other similar films from recent years. May not even be showing by christmas.
Thanks Saul for the observation. I will take my chances and leave the prediction as 75% based only on the probability that it will boost on the last week of the year.

Current Earnings of Jurassic World is at $1.6 billion and Titanic at $ 2.2 billion. Jurassic has almost caught up with Titanic in Box-office earnings but it's almost $500 mn behind in International earnings. Chances very less of catching up unless a bumper holiday viewing abroad..
it has as much chance as El Stinko II
Based on last weekend's box office, box office down 39% to 118k. Maths no longer works even if it remained constant, which it won't. The battle is over and the film will fall short by $5m.

Not going to happen.
There isn't enough supporting evidence on the trend to show that it will be able to have the staying power, especially with movies such as "Star Wars" being released soon.
No. It simply wasn't that good. And now that the hype has died off, I can't imagine it'll make that much more by the end of the year.

Forecast has been zero'd out for a while. Not expecting this to happen this year, but, it seems Universal might be motivated, at some point, to give a final push to JW, just to claim bragging rights for the #2 film.

It made 1 billion dollars in 13 days. Since then, the average weekly take isn't enough to get it over Titanic's revenues by the end of the year. It'll be close, but there are other huge films out, (Bond and Star Wars) which will distract most casual film goers.
There's not enough time for it to pass Titanic.
Too many other shows coming out around the same time will siphon off the revenues

While Jurassic World struck a nerve (and hit the perfect window for release) the dropping gross revenue this time of year, and the release of some potential mega-blockbusters right at the end of the year will probably keep Jurassic from passing that mark by the end of the year.
Not enough weeks left between now and the end of 2015.

Weekly gross is about a quarter million. It needs a total of 7 million to beat Titanic. Won't make it by at least a factor of 3. 
http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekly&id=jurassicpark4.htm

Currently per http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/domestic.htm the takings are - Titanic: $658,672,302. Jurassic World:$651,771,446. JW has to earn $6,900,856 (6.9 million) in the next 8.5 weeks. The rate of decline in JW takings (averaging 29% per week from weeks 14 to 20) is actually decreasing.
I have barely heard anything about this movie,  since everyone flooded to the theaters.  Titanic is a high bar.
To make up the ~$7m gap, JW would need to maintain its most recent week's gross for ~23 weeks.
time is running out and avg. weekly keeps going down.  Could see some bumps if it makes it to the holidays, but won't be enough.

The rate of box office sales through October is NOT enough to add to Jurassic World's total to overcome Titanic.  Something statistically abnormal would have to occur, and an abnormality is much likely to slow sales further than to speed them up.  Especially with hot new films hitting soon, like "Bond" and others.

The only reason I left the 1% chance up there was in case there was a Christmas theatrical re-release. it was a rather dissappointing movie for many key critics. It was well marketed and doing fine in the box office, but its still rather far from the success of Titanic

I've been seeing ads around the net about DVD availability on October 20. Universal appears to have respected the release window for Jurrasic World to support boxoffice sales. I've been unable to find by how much DVD sales erode box office sales. This may be the (final) nail in the coffin.

Leaving historical forecasts to cover any remaining probability of occurance.

The only bump it could likely get would be Thanksgiving week, but similar hits got little hit if Thanksgiving was late in their run.  That would also require 6 more weeks which would be beyond the typical length listed by BOM of 22ish weeks.  JW is also now in only a few hundred theaters and so is highly unlikely to be able to generate the 8 million it currently needs by the end of the year.  If it stayed in all of those theaters it probably would not generate enough and it is unlikely to stay in enough to bother measuring for more than another couple of weeks.

hard to beat titanic in the repeat viewers arena.

TItanic stands at a domestic gross of ~658,672k including the '97 release and '12 re-release in 3D. Jurassic work is currently at 650,052k as of September 24th. This deficit of 8,620k will have to be made up before it is phased out of theaters. In the last two weeks, it has lost 60% and 45% of weekly gross from ~3.6M Sept. 4-10 to ~828k from Sept. 18-24. It opened with 4,274 theaters and is down to 753.
Following the crowd. Decreased screen count was main factor.

Lowering this too.  The run rate has predictably dropped to slightly over $1m a week.  Which means there's very little margin for error now.

To bypass  "Titanic", additional ticket sales would have to be $8,811,781 or more.    Checking the link above, it seems the weekly gross sales decrease from an approximate 30 - 50% from the previous week over time.   In this movie the last few weekly changes were highly variable but possibly related to the long holiday weekend or other factors.   From September 4 - 10 weekly gross declined by 9.6% but the following week, September 11 - 17, declined by 59.5%.   The average decline for those is 34.5%.  This is within the range of weekly gross decline earlier for this movie as well as seen for a number of other movies as mentioned above.   So, estimating the weekly gross based on a 34.5% decrease by week calculated to be an additional 2.7 Million by week 8 at which time the weekly gross was estimated, using this concept, to be around $51,000.    Assuming the movie continued to run through the end of the year (14 weeks) based on this approach the movie will have made no more than an additional 2.83 Million by the end of the year, much less than the 8.8 million necessary to pass Titanic.

Actually looking at the numbers it seems like it could make $9MM more in 16 weeks, that's $560K/week spread across entire US.  It's still in 5 theaters in my area.  Let's say it stays in 5 theaters in 50 states, that's 250 theaters, so it's got to make $2,250/theater/week or $321/day.  Let's say tickets are discounted in the Podunk theaters to $8/seat.  That's 40 tickets per day.  Lets say there are 4 showtimes in the Podunk theaters.  That's 10 tickets per theater per showtime.  I think that's doable.

Data: Using weekly domestic earnings data from http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies I compared Jurassic World actual earnings to date against previously successful movies on the top 20 all time earnings list. I focused on these high grossing movies because they likely have a lifespan in theaters most analogous to JW, and I used only movies from the recent past (farthest back I went was 2012) so as to avoid, as much as possible, historical fluctuations in moviegoer attendance, changes in average ticket price, and other compounding factors.

Romance does not flourish in a violent environment.  The giant creatures terrifying humans are much more in sync with today's scary world, and we often want to see movies that reflect the world.  They teach us how to act/react.

I looked up the weekly gross at Box Office Mojo [1].  The main pattern is a steady decline in weekly gross of about 40% or so each week.  There was a sudden bump on the weekend of August 29th, followed by continuing decline (I assume the bump was caused by release to secondary theatres, or something like that).  If the decline continues at the 40% rate, Jurassic World will make another $2million or so, well short of the $9million it needs to overtake Titanic.  Other similar movies (see [2] for Marvel's The Avengers) seem to follow a similar pattern, with a single bump in gross.

Agree with Tylerh/Ratel. The release to "dollar theaters" for both movies increased takings by hundreds of %, occurring in week 31 for Titanic (316%), and week 12 (203%) for Jurassic World. The takings dropped in week 13 for JW, even though the number of theaters increased compared to week 12. For Titanic, the median weekly drop in takings after the DCB event is 25.65%. Assuming a similar or steeper drop for JW (because weekly takings are falling much more steeply compared to the equivalent time periods for Titanic), JW will probably not cross the threshold in time.

The movie has so far made $648 million in 64 days. It still has 109 days to make the remaining 11 million. For the past 28 days the movie has made $1.7 million per day on average. Even if that average falls to $0.1 million per day for the rest of the year, Jurassic World will pass Titanic by the end of December. All data from Wikipedia.

The GJP people should really clarify for us what site/s they will use to decide when the threshold crosses over. But assuming its boxofficemojo, and just going off GJDrew's analysis, I don't think JW will surpass Titanic. Since based on what movies will be coming out within the next few weeks ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_in_film ), I think cinemas will probably stop showing JW before or around the 22 weeks that GJDrew mentioned. Also, other films by Universal Studios (which made JW) are coming out soon, which might affect whether JW remains in cinemas (although I don't really know how such things work in cinemas, but just a guess).

At the moment, the gap looks too big to fill before January.  (I'm assuming the criterion is theatre gross in uninflated dollars, not including home video, broadcast rights, and whatnot.  If that stuff is included, Jurassic has no chance in the short term.)
